questions.text: A known case of ulcerative colitis is not responding to an anti-TNF alpha agent. Which JAK inhibitor is preferred for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tofacitinib

 

Explanation:

  • Tofacitinib is a oral JAK inhibitor that works by inhibiting the JAK-STAT pathway, which regulates cytokine-mediated inflammation.
  • It is approved for the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, particularly in patients who are refractory or intolerant to anti-TNF agents like infliximab or adalimumab.

 

  • Tofacitinib is a JAK 1/3 inhibitor and blocks the production of inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-6 and interferons.
  • It is effective for inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.

 

  • Side effects include an increased risk of infections, venous thromboembolism, and lipid elevation, requiring careful patient selection and monitoring.

 

Vedolizumab (Option A) is an anti-integrin monoclonal antibody targeting α4β7 integrin, used to treat moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

 

Ozanimod (Option C) is an FDA-approved sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P1) receptor modulator for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, reducing lymphocyte migration to the gut.

 

Leflunomide (Option D) is a pyrimidine synthesis inhibitor primarily for rheumatoid arthritis treatment.

questions.text: 24-year-old female presents with dysphagia, weight loss and bronchiectasis. Which investigation should be done to confirm the diagnosis. Barium swallow was shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Esophageal manometry

Explanation: The barium swallow in this patient shows the classic bird-beak appearance suggestive of achalasia cardia. While barium swallow can suggest the diagnosis, the gold standard test for confirmation is esophageal manometry, which demonstrates incomplete lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.

Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is characterized by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus.

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia such as tumors.

Upper GI endoscopy (Option B): Useful to rule out malignancy (pseudoachalasia) and assess mucosa, but does not confirm motility disorder.

CT chest (Option C): Helpful in detecting mediastinal masses or external compression, but not diagnostic for achalasia.

CECT chest (Option D): Similar to CT chest, used to rule out secondary causes but not confirm the motility disorder.

questions.text: Which classification is used for Barrett esophagus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Prague classification:

Explanation:

  • The Prague C & M classification is used for Barrett esophagus, where C denotes the circumferential extent of the Barrett mucosa and M denotes the maximal extent from the gastroesophageal junction, as measured endoscopically.
  • It helps in standardizing reporting and guiding surveillance.

Prague Classification

  • Two key measurements:
    • C (Circumferential extent)
    • M (Maximum extent)
  • Circumferential extent
    • Distance (in cm) from the GE junction to the proximal limit of circumferential Barrett's mucosa
  • Maximum extent:
    • Distance from the GE junction to the furthest proximal extension of any Barrett's mucosa (including tongues or islands)
  • Example:
    • If Barrett's mucosa is circumferentially present for 3 cm, and a tongue extends up to 6 cm:
      • Prague classification = C3M6

Incorrect Options:

Savary-Miller classification (Option B): Used for grading reflux esophagitis severity based on endoscopic findings.

Johnson classification (Option C): Used for types of gastroesophageal reflux depending on the location of the lower esophageal sphincter and diaphragm.

Forrest classification (Option D): Used in upper GI bleeding to describe peptic ulcer bleeding stigmata and predict rebleeding risk.

questions.text: A patient has cheilosis with koilonychia and anemia. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Plummer-Vinson syndrome:

Explanation:

  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by the triad of iron deficiency anemia, esophageal webs, and glossitis/cheilosis.
  • Koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails) and cheilosis (cracking at the corners of the mouth) are classic signs of iron deficiency.
  • This syndrome increases the risk of developing esophageal squamous cell carcinoma if untreated.

Incorrect Options:

Esophageal cancer (Option B): May develop as a complication of Plummer-Vinson syndrome but is not a presenting diagnosis with these features.

Achalasia cardia (Option C): Presents with dysphagia and esophageal motility disorder, but without anemia or cheilosis.

Tylosis palmaris (Option D): A genetic disorder causing thickened skin on palms and soles, unrelated to anemia or cheilosis.

questions.text: A patient with osteoarthritis, for the last 3 months, has been taking ibuprofen and has developed occult GI bleeding. Which is correct about the cause?

choices.text: PGE-2 and prostacyclin production were reduced
PGE-1 and prostacyclin production were reduced
Mucosal injury due to inhibition of COX-2

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - PGE-2 and prostacyclin production were reduced:

Explanation:

  • NSAIDs like ibuprofen inhibit COX enzymes, reducing prostaglandin (PGE₂) and prostacyclin synthesis. These mediators normally maintain gastric mucosal protection by increasing mucus and bicarbonate secretion and promoting mucosal blood flow.
  • Loss of PGE₂ and prostacyclin leads to impaired gastric mucosal defense, making the mucosa susceptible to acid-induced injury and bleeding. This is the primary mechanism for NSAID-induced gastritis and peptic ulcers. COX-1 inhibition is particularly responsible for GI side effects, as it is involved in constitutive prostaglandin synthesis for mucosal protection.

NSAID-induced GI injury:

  • Mechanism: COX-1 inhibition → ↓ PGE₂, ↓ prostacyclin → ↓ mucus, ↓ bicarbonate, ↓ blood flow.
  • Risk factors: High-dose/long-term NSAID use, elderly, alcohol, corticosteroids, H. pylori infection.
  • Prevention: Co-prescription of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) or misoprostol (PGE₁ analog).
  • Histology: Superficial mucosal erosions with inflammatory infiltrates.
  • Complications: Peptic ulcers, GI bleeding, perforation.

Incorrect Options:

Increased acid production (Option B): NSAIDs do not significantly increase gastric acid secretion; the main issue is reduced mucosal defense.

PGE-1 and prostacyclin production reduced (Option C): The main gastric protective prostaglandin is PGE₂, not PGE₁.

Mucosal injury due to inhibition of COX-2 (Option D): COX-2 inhibition is more linked to anti-inflammatory effects and cardiovascular risk, not primary GI mucosal damage (which is COX-1–mediated).

questions.text: A patient with inflammatory bowel disease presents with the following lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pyoderma gangrenosum

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Pyoderma gangrenosum which is more common in Ulcerative colitis a type of inflammatory bowel disease.

  • Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare, inflammatory skin condition characterized by the development of painful, ulcerative lesions.
  • It can occur in patients with inflammatory bowel disease, and the lower limbs are a common site of involvement.
  • The ulcers typically have undermined borders and may have a necrotic or purulent appearance.

Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD:

  • Erythema nodosum (A skin condition characterized by painful red nodules typically found on the shins). (Option A)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis (Arthritis of the spine)
  • Pancreatitis
  • Uveitis (Inflammation of the uvea)
  • Osteoporosis and Osteonecrosis are overall the most common extra-intestinal manifestations of IBD.
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum is common in Ulcerative colitis.
  • Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis is common in Ulcerative colitis.
  • Renal calculi is common in Crohn’s disease.

Diabetic ulcer (Option C) is not associated with inflammatory bowel disease. It is a complication of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.

Venous ulcer (Option D) is usually caused by conditions like long-standing varicose veins. It is usually situated around the ankles.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, bone pain and abdominal distension. Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody

Explanation: The clinical scenario of fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss, bone pain, abdominal distension, iron deficiency anemia, and osteoporosis strongly indicates celiac disease. The single best test for its evaluation is the IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody.

Celiac Disease:

  • Also called celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy.
  • Associated with HLA-DQ2 and DQ8.
  • Small intestinal enteropathy caused by immune response to gluten.
  • Characterized by autoantibodies to tissue transglutaminase.
  • Gluten is found in wheat, rye, barley, and some oats.
  • Pathogenesis: Tissue transglutaminase deamidates glutamine residues of gluten-derived peptides, facilitating immune response.
  • Affects the proximal small intestine.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Diarrhea, weight loss, growth failure (children).
    • Bloating, irregular bowel habits, migraines, ataxia.
    • May present with osteoporosis, iron-deficiency anemia, or abnormal liver enzymes.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum antibodies: Tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, deamidated anti-gliadin antibodies.
    • Measure serum IgA levels to detect IgA deficiency.
  • Confirmatory testing:
    • Endoscopy with small-intestinal biopsy.
    • Biopsy findings: Villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, increased intraepithelial lymphocytes.
    • Marsh classification used for severity grading.
  • Management: Lifelong strict gluten-free diet.

 

TSH levels (Option A): Thyroid dysfunction can cause fatigue and weight loss, but it does not explain chronic diarrhea, iron deficiency anemia, or osteoporosis. These symptoms point toward malabsorption rather than thyroid disease, making TSH an inappropriate choice in this context.

C-peptide levels (Option B): C-peptide is useful in evaluating insulin secretion and distinguishing between type 1 and type 2 diabetes. However, diabetes does not typically present with chronic diarrhea, iron deficiency anemia, or osteoporosis, making it irrelevant here.

Urine sugar and ketones (Option C): While this test helps identify diabetes and diabetic ketoacidosis, the patient's symptoms, such as malabsorption and nutrient deficiencies, do not suggest these conditions. Chronic diarrhea and weight loss are not hallmark features of diabetes.

questions.text: What is not a characteristic feature of Wilson's disease?

choices.text: Presents before age 40 with liver disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) No Free radical injury

Explanation:

  • Free radical injury due to an excess of copper ions is seen in patients with Wilson's disease.

Wilson's disease

  • Wilson's disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder (Option A), usually presents before age 40 (Option D) with liver disease caused by the abnormal accumulation of copper in the liver, brain, eyes, and other organs. This results in elevated free copper levels, along with increased copper levels in the liver and urine, while serum ceruloplasmin levels are decreased.

Gene Affected:

  • The disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene (Option C) on chromosome 13. This gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase responsible for excreting copper from the liver into bile.

Pathogenesis:
 

Lab parameters of Wilson’s disease

Parameter

Change

Explanation

Free Copper

⬆️ Increased

Unbound copper elevated due to impaired binding.

Liver Copper

⬆️ Increased

Accumulation due to defective biliary excretion.

Urinary Copper

⬆️ Increased

Overflow from the liver leads to high excretion.

Total Copper

⬇️ Decreased

Mainly composed of ceruloplasmin-bound copper.

Serum Ceruloplasmin

⬇️ Decreased

Defective incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of a patient who has significant abdominal swelling and laboratory analysis of the fluid obtained through paracentesis reveals SAAG <1.1?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • Among the given options, only in tuberculosis SAAG score will be < 1.1 mg/dl, all others will have SAAG >1.1mg/dl.
  • Congestive heart failure (Option A) can also lead to the development of ascites. However, in this, the SAAG is usually greater than 1.1 g/dL.
  • SAAG is usually greater than 1.1 g/dL in myxoedema (Option B)and Budd Chiari syndrome (Option C).

Interpretations of SAAG:

  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL: Portal hypertension (ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids)
    • Ascitic protein level ≥2.5 g/dL: Hepatic sinusoids are normal (allows passage of protein)
    • Ascitic protein level <2.5 g/dL: Hepatic sinusoids are damaged and scarred (no passage of protein)
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL: Ascites is not related to portal hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following are not included in the components of the MELD (2016) score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Albumin

Explanation:

  • Albumin is included in the calculation of the PELD (Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease) and not the MELD (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) score.

MELD (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) score:

  • Predicts prognosis in chronic liver disease
  • It was developed to predict 3-month mortality in patients after TIPSS (transjugular portosystemic shunt)
  • Used in UNOS (United Nations Organ Sharing Network) to determine priority for liver transplantation.
  • Most patients with low MELD scores (less than 15) do not benefit from transplantation
  • Score: 6 - 40

Components:

  • Creatinine (Option D)
  • Bilirubin (Option A)
  • INR (Option B)

PELD (Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease) Score:

  • Used to determine priority for children awaiting liver transplantation
  • Components:
    • Nutrition
    • Age
    • Bilirubin
    • INR
    • Albumin

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11

 

Explanation:

  • HLA-DQ6 and HLA-DQ11 are not associated with celiac disease.
  • In contrast, HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 are the primary genetic markers found in almost all individuals with celiac disease.
  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion in genetically predisposed individuals.
  • It primarily affects the proximal small intestine, with the duodenum most commonly involved.
  • In some cases, it extends to the jejunum, causing more severe symptoms.

Pathophysiology:

  • Genetics: HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 are associated with celiac disease.
  • Immune Response: Gluten ingestion triggers inflammation in the small intestine

Symptoms:

  • Gastrointestinal: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, vomiting, steatorrhea.
  • Extra-intestinal: Fatigue, skin rashes (dermatitis herpetiformis), weight loss, anemia, joint pain, headaches, peripheral neuropathy.
  • In Children: Delayed growth, irritability, poor weight gain, bone issues due to malabsorption.

Diagnosis:

1. Serological Testing:

  • Tissue Transglutaminase (tTG) Antibodies: Most sensitive and specific test. (Option A ruled out)
  • Anti-Endomysial Antibodies (EMA)
  • Anti-Gliadin Antibodies (AGA): Less specific. (Option B ruled out)

2. Histological Confirmation:

  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is the gold standard.
  • Histological Changes:
    • Villous Atrophy: Flattened villi.
  • Crypt Hyperplasia: Increased crypt cells.
  • Intraepithelial Lymphocytosis: Elevated lymphocytes.

3. Histological Grading (Modified Marsh Classification): (Option C ruled out)

 

Type

Definition

0

Normal duodenal biopsy

I

Normal mucosal architecture with increased intraepithelial lymphocytes

II

Hyperplastic crypts, but near normal Villi

IIIa

Hyperplastic crypts with partial villous atrophy

IIIb

Hyperplastic crypts with subtotal villous atrophy

IIIc

Hyperplastic crypts with total villous atrophy

 

Treatment:

  • Gluten-Free Diet: Lifelong, strict adherence is the only treatment.
  • Gluten-containing foods (BROW): Barley, Rye, Oats, Wheat.

Complications:

  • Malnutrition: Due to impaired absorption.
  • Osteoporosis: From poor calcium and vitamin D absorption.
  • Intestinal Lymphoma and Small Bowel Cancer: Rare but serious.
  • Increased Risk of Autoimmune Disorders: Such as Type 1 diabetes and autoimmune thyroid disease.

 

Feature

Coeliac Sprue

Whipple's Disease

Tropical Sprue

Description
  • Autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten.
  • Systemic infectious disease caused by Tropheryma whipplei.
  • Malabsorption disorder seen in tropical regions.
  • Cause often unknown, possibly infectious.

Etiology
  • Genetic predisposition (HLA-DQ2/DQ8).
  • Environmental trigger: gluten (present in wheat, barley, rye) ingestion and an immune response to gliadin, a protein in gluten.

Infection with Tropheryma whipplei, found in soil and sewage.
  • Possibly due to bacterial, fungal or coronavirus infection.

Clinical Features

Affects mainly proximal small intestine.

 

Intestinal Features:

  • Chronic diarrhea or steatorrhea.
  • Malabsorption: weight loss, vitamin deficiencies.
  • Abdominal pain, bloating.
 

Extraintestinal Features:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis (in some cases).

Affects mainly distal small intestine.

 

Intestinal Features:

  • Chronic diarrhea.
  • Malabsorption, weight loss.
  • Abdominal pain and bloating.
 

Extraintestinal Features:

  • Arthralgia (joint pain).
  • Fever.
  • Lymphadenopathy.
  • Neurological symptoms (cognitive impairment, seizures, ataxia in advanced stages, oculomasticatory myorhythmia).
  • Uveitis
  • Cardiac involvement (rare).

Affects entire small intestinal

 

Intestinal Features:

  • Chronic diarrhea.
  • Malabsorption, weight loss.
  • Abdominal pain, bloating.
 

Extraintestinal Features:

  • Anemia (often megaloblastic).

Histological Findings
 
  • Loss or flattening of intestinal villi (villous atrophy).
  • Hyperplastic crypts (crypt elongation).
  • Increased infiltration of lymphocytes, especially CD8+ T cells.
  • Increased plasma cells, lymphocytes, macrophages in lamina propria.
 
  • Villous blunting and atrophy.
  • Dense infiltration of lamina propria by macrophages containing PAS-positive granules.
  • Foamy macrophages laden with Tropheryma whipplei in various tissues (e.g., lymph nodes, CNS, synovial fluid).
 
  • Villous atrophy.
  • Crypt hyperplasia.
  • Increased inflammatory cells (similar to Celiac disease but without gliadin-specific immune response).

Investigations

Biopsy

Serologic Tests:

  • Most sensitive and most common antibody test: Anti-Tissue Transglutaminase Antibodies (Anti-tTG) - IgA and IgG
  • Most specific antibody test: Anti-Endomysial Antibodies (EMA) - IgA.
  • Anti-Deamidated Gliadin Peptide (DGP) Antibodies - IgA and IgG.
  • Anti-Gliadin Antibodies (AGA) - IgA and IgG.

Biopsy

PCR for Tropheryma whipplei DNA.

Immunohistochemistry for Tropheryma whipplei.

Biopsy

Response to Treatment: Antibiotic response helps confirm diagnosis.

Management
  • Lifelong gluten-free diet.
  • Nutritional supplementation: iron, folate, calcium, vitamin D.
  • Indications for steroids:
    • Refractory disease for 6-12 months
    • Celiac crisis
    • Lymphoma
  • Monitoring for complications

Prolonged antibiotic therapy:

  • Initially IV ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks.
  • Followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a year.
  • Tetracycline for 6 months.
  • Folate supplementation.
  • Some recommend a gluten-free diet.

Complications
  • Osteoporosis.
  • Malignancy (e.g., small bowel lymphoma).
  • Infertility.
  • Neurological complications (rare).
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Untreated disease can be fatal due to multi-organ involvement.
  • Relapses are common (especially CNS).
  • Nutritional deficiencies can lead to osteoporosis, cachexia.
  • Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12, folate).
  • Persistent malabsorption.
  • Possible relapse and chronic diarrhea.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of dysphagia, particularly for solids, which has been progressively worsening over the past few months. Additionally, he has experienced significant weight loss and cachexia over the same period. Which of the following diagnostic choices is best for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) UGIE (Upper GI Endoscopy)

Explanation:

  • The presentation of progressive dysphagia for solids with significant weight loss and cachexia in an elderly patient strongly suggests esophageal carcinoma.
  • Upper GI endoscopy (UGIE) is the gold standard diagnostic tool in this scenario as it allows direct visualization of the tumor and enables tissue biopsy for definitive diagnosis. UGIE also permits thorough examination of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, which is crucial as this population has a higher risk of head and neck malignancies. Additionally, CT scanning of the chest and abdomen is typically performed to assess tumor spread to mediastinal and para-aortic lymph nodes.

Manometry (Option B): While manometry is useful in diagnosing esophageal motility disorders such as achalasia, it is not the appropriate first-line investigation when malignancy is suspected (Option B ruled out). Manometry cannot provide visual confirmation of tumors or allow for tissue sampling.

Barium swallow (Option C): Although barium swallow can demonstrate mucosal abnormalities and strictures, it cannot provide tissue diagnosis which is essential when malignancy is suspected (Option C ruled out). It may be used as a complementary study but should not be the primary diagnostic tool in this scenario.

Barium meal follow through (Option D): This study is primarily used to evaluate the small intestine and is not appropriate for investigating suspected esophageal pathology (Option D ruled out). It would not provide the necessary information about the esophageal lesion or allow for tissue sampling.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male is experiencing recurring episodes of watery diarrhea, dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Which type of neuroendocrine tumor could potentially cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - VIPoma

  • The clinical manifestations indicate a VIPoma (vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumor), which is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that causes WDHA syndrome (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, and Achlorhydria).
  • This condition is characterized by secretory diarrhea due to excessive VIP production, leading to profound fluid and electrolyte losses. The syndrome presents with severe watery diarrhea (up to 3L/day), resulting in dehydration, electrolyte imbalances particularly hypokalemia, and decreased gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria). The excessive VIP secretion directly causes these symptoms through its effects on intestinal and gastric secretion.

VIPoma

Definition:
  • A VIPoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumour that produces vasoactive intestinal peptides (VIP).
  • They are linked to syndromes like:
    • Verner-Morrison syndrome.
    • Pancreatic cholera.
    • WDHA syndrome (watery diarrhoea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria).
  • VIP, a 28-amino-acid peptide, mimics cholera toxin effects by:
    • Stimulating chloride secretion in the small intestine.
    • Increasing smooth muscle contractility.
    • Leading to severe diarrhoea.

Clinical features:

Patients typically present with:

  • Severe watery diarrhoea leads to hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.
  • Flushing episodes.
  • Low stomach acid (achlorhydria/hypochlorhydria).
  • Increased glycogen breakdown.
  • Elevated calcium levels (hypercalcemia).

Tumor Characteristics:
  • Typically solitary.
  • Often located in the pancreatic tail.

Diagnosis:
  • Elevated plasma VIP levels are common but not definitive for diagnosis, as they can occur in other conditions like:
    • Inflammatory bowel disease.
    • Post-surgery (small bowel resection).
    • Radiation enteritis.
  • Chronic laxative or diuretic use can complicate diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Critical management includes:
    • Fluid and electrolyte replacement to address dehydration, hypokalemia, and electrolyte losses.
  • Long-term treatment options:
    • Somatostatin analogues are effective in controlling diarrhoea.
    • Surgical resection is recommended for localized tumours.

Insulinoma (Option A): An insulinoma presents with symptoms of hypoglycemia including weakness, fatigue, sweating, palpitations, confusion, and seizures. These tumors produce excess insulin, leading to low blood sugar, but do not cause the profound diarrhea and electrolyte disturbances seen in this patient.

Somatostatinoma (Option B): Somatostatinomas typically present with diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, diarrhea, and steatorrhea due to somatostatin's inhibitory effects on digestive enzyme secretion. While diarrhea can occur, the complete WDHA syndrome is not a feature of this tumor.

Glucagonoma (Option D): Glucagonomas are characterized by necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes mellitus, weight loss, and anemia. They do not typically cause the severe secretory diarrhea and electrolyte abnormalities seen in this case.

questions.text: A patient was taking ampicillin for an upper respiratory tract infection. Then he started having watery diarrhoea for the past 3 days. Which is the drug of choice to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fidaxomicin

Explanation:

  • The overuse of antibiotics like ampicillin leads to diarrhoea and further, a condition called pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile and is treated with Fidaxomicin.

 

Clostridioides Difficile Infection (CDI)

  • A colonic disease caused by C. difficile, linked to antibiotic use disrupting normal gut microbiome.
  • It results in diarrhoea and severe cases, of pseudomembranous colitis (PMC).

Etiology & Epidemiology:

  • C. difficile is a spore-forming, anaerobic bacterium.
  • Most commonly acquired in hospitals, nursing homes, and after antibiotic use.
  • High-risk antibiotics: Clindamycin, Ampicillin, Cephalosporins, and Fluoroquinolones (Option C).
  • CDI is common in healthcare settings and can also occur in the community without prior antibiotic use.

Pathogenesis:

  • Ingestion of spores leads to toxin production (Toxin A and Toxin B) causing gut damage, diarrhoea, and PMC.
  • Toxin B is the more important virulence factor.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on diarrhoea (≥3 unformed stools/day for ≥2 days).
  • Toxin detection in stool (via PCR or enzyme immunoassays).
  • Endoscopy can detect PMC in advanced cases.

Treatment:

  • First-line:
    • Oral Vancomycin or Fidaxomicin
    • Metronidazole is an alternative for mild cases. (Option A)
  • Hydration and avoiding antiperistaltic agents are recommended.
  • For severe cases, Oral Vancomycin is preferred, especially if the patient is seriously ill.
  • IV Vancomycin is ineffective.


Bezlotoxumab (Option D) is a monoclonal antibody against C.difficile toxin B used in recurrent pseudomembranous colitis as an adjunct with vancomycin, fidaxomicin or metronidazole. It is not the first-line treatment for this condition.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with complaints of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and cramps. An endoscopy is done and she is diagnosed with ulcerative colitis. She currently has 3-4 episodes of bloody stools per day. What is the appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sulfasalazine

Explanation:

  • Sulfasalazine is commonly used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis (inflammatory bowel disease).

Sulfasalazine

Anti-inflammatory Properties:

  • Sulfasalazine is composed of two components: Sulfapyridine and 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA).
  • The 5-ASA component is responsible for the drug's anti-inflammatory effects.
  • It inhibits the production of inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes, which play a role in the inflammation seen in ulcerative colitis.

Immunomodulatory Effects:

  • Sulfasalazine also has immunomodulatory effects, which help to regulate the immune response in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • By modulating the activity of immune cells such as macrophages and T cells, sulfasalazine can reduce inflammation.

Antibacterial Activity:

  • Sulfasalazine's sulfapyridine component has antibacterial properties.
  • It acts by disrupting the metabolism of certain bacteria, particularly those in the gut microbiota.
  • By targeting bacteria, sulfasalazine may help to restore balance to the gut microbiome.

Local Action in the Colon:

  • Sulfasalazine is administered orally, and its 5-ASA component is not absorbed systemically to a significant extent.
  • Instead, it remains largely in the colon, where it exerts its anti-inflammatory effects directly on the inflamed tissue.
  • This targeted action reduces the risk of systemic side effects commonly associated with corticosteroids or other systemic immunosuppressive agents.

Maintenance Therapy:

  • Sulfasalazine is often used as maintenance therapy in ulcerative colitis.
  • It helps prevent flare-ups and maintain remission over the long term.

Symptomatic Relief:

  • In addition to its disease-modifying effects, sulfasalazine can provide symptomatic relief from the symptoms of ulcerative colitis, such as diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and rectal bleeding.

Incorrect Options:

Budesonide (Option A) is used in cases of exacerbation of ulcerative colitis, especially mild to moderate cases.

Azathioprine (AZA) (Option C) is a medication used in the management and treatment of active rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and the prevention of kidney transplant rejection.

Bezlotoxumab (Option D) is indicated to reduce the recurrence of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) in patients who are receiving antibacterial drug treatment for CDI and are at high risk for CDI recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms suggests the use of steroids in IgA vasculitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Gastrointestinal hemorrhage: 

  • Steroids are administered in cases of gastrointestinal bleeding or suspected perforation to mitigate inflammation and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is pneumomediastinum commonly found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Boerhaave syndrome

Explanation:

  • Pneumomediastinum is one of the complication associated with Boerhaave syndrome, which is a condition characterized by spontaneous full-thickness rupture of the esophagus.
  • Boerhaave syndrome clinically manifests as Mackler’s triad (Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema). The condition is often preceded by forceful vomiting.
  • This condition typically occurs in the lower third of the esophagus and results in a direct communication between the esophageal lumen and mediastinal space. The rupture allows esophageal contents to spill into the mediastinum which can occasionally lead to complications such as pneumomediastinum and chemical mediastinitis.

 

Boerhaave syndrome

Definition

It is a spontaneous esophageal rupture caused by a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure, typically from vomiting against a closed glottis resulting in a left-sided esophageal perforation, which allows gastric contents to spill into the pleural cavity, leading to a left pleural effusion and subcutaneous emphysema.

Classic triad

Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema. (Mackler’s triad)

Other Symptoms

May include fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea in the presence of sepsis

Physical examination

Hamman’s sign (crunching sound on auscultation due to surgical emphysema).

Complications

Pneumothorax/Pneumomediastinum, mediastinitis, and sepsis.

 

Pulsion diverticulum (Option A) occurs due to increased intraluminal pressure in the esophagus, forming an outpouching of the esophageal wall. While it can cause symptoms like dysphagia and regurgitation, it does not typically result in pneumomediastinum as the esophageal wall remains intact.

Mallory-Weiss syndrome (Option C) involves longitudinal mucosal tears at the gastroesophageal junction, typically following forceful vomiting. While it can cause hematemesis, the tear is superficial and does not extend through the full thickness of the esophageal wall, thus not causing pneumomediastinum.

Pericarditis (Option D) is inflammation of the pericardium, the fibrous sac surrounding the heart. While it causes chest pain and other symptoms related to inflammation, it does not involve the esophagus and does not cause pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease.

choices.text: Skip lesions are present in Crohn’s disease
Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn’s while transmural involvement seen in ulcerative colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease doesn’t have a genetic predisposition
Crohn’s is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.solution:
Skip lesions refer to the characteristic feature of Crohn's disease where there are areas of inflammation that are separated by normal or unaffected segments of the bowel. This pattern of involvement is not seen in ulcerative colitis. Skip lesions can occur throughout the entire gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, in Crohn's disease.

 

In Crohn's disease, the inflammation can involve all layers of the bowel wall, which is known as transmural involvement. In ulcerative colitis, the inflammation is limited to the mucosal layer of the colon and rectum. (Option B)

 

Both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis have a strong genetic component, indicating a predisposition to developing these conditions (Option C). Family history of inflammatory bowel disease is a known risk factor.

 

Crohn's disease is a chronic condition that requires long-term management and treatment (Option D) to control inflammation and maintain remission.

questions.text: In what situations is surgery contraindicated for patients with Ulcerative Colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Crohn’s disease:

  • Crohn’s disease: Presence of crohn’s disease is a contraindication of surgery in ulcerative colitis due to high rates of fistula formation, obstruction, and leakage.

Incorrect options:

Option B, C, D - These are indications for surgery in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products. On investigation, he was found to have a lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Yogurt

  • Lactose intolerance is a condition characterized by the inability to digest lactose, a sugar found in dairy products caused due to deficiency of lactase responsible to breakdown lactose.
  • Yogurt is produced through the fermentation of milk by bacteria, typically Lactobacillus and Streptococcus species. During the fermentation process, these bacteria produce lactase, which helps break down lactose into simpler sugars. As a result, yogurt contains lower levels of lactose compared to other dairy products.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Condensed Milk: Condensed milk is milk from which water has been removed, resulting in a concentrated form. It contains a high concentration of lactose, and therefore, is likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance in individuals with lactase deficiency.

Option B - Skimmed Milk: Skimmed milk refers to milk from which the cream (high-fat portion) has been removed. While the fat content is reduced, lactose content remains relatively unchanged. Therefore, skimmed milk can still cause symptoms of lactose intolerance in individuals with lactase deficiency.

Option D - Ice Cream: Ice cream is a dairy product that typically contains high amounts of lactose. Therefore, ice cream is likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance in individuals with lactase deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least chance of developing malignancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oral lichen planus:

  • Oral lichen planus (OLP) is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the mucous membranes in the mouth.
  • Conditions associated with low risk malignant transformation
    • Oral lichen planus
    • Discoid lupus erythematosus
    • Discoid kerratosis congenita

Incorrect Options:

Option A - (Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis) is incorrect because chronic hyperplastic candidiasis, caused by the fungus Candida, is considered a premalignant condition due to its association with an increased risk of oral cancer.

Option B - (Oral submucosal fibrosis) is incorrect because oral submucosal fibrosis, typically caused by the chewing of betel nuts or other irritants, is considered a premalignant condition associated with an increased risk of oral cancer.

Option D - (Leukoplakia) is incorrect because leukoplakia, characterized by white patches in the oral mucosa, is considered a premalignant condition as it has a higher risk of progressing to oral cancer.

questions.text: A 40-year-old was brought to the emergency with complians of severe abdominal pain with tenderness, fever with chills, and tachycardia. What is the most likely diagnosis for the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumoperitoneum:

  • The correct diagnosis based on the given description and the X-ray image showing air under the diaphragm is pneumoperitoneum.
  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, which is the space between the abdominal organs and the abdominal wall. It is commonly caused by perforation or rupture of a hollow organ in the abdomen, such as the stomach, intestine, or appendix. The presence of air under the diaphragm on an X-ray image is a classic finding seen in pneumoperitoneum.
  •  

Incorrect options:

Option A - Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax refers to the presence of air or gas in the pleural cavity, which is the space between the lung and the chest wall. It typically appears as air surrounding the lung tissue on an X-ray image.

Option C - Eventration of diaphragm: Eventration of the diaphragm is a condition in which the diaphragm muscle is abnormally thin or weak, leading to an elevated and dome-shaped appearance. It does not involve the presence of air under the diaphragm.

Option D - Pneumomediastinum: Pneumomediastinum refers to the presence of air or gas in the mediastinum, which is the central region of the chest between the lungs. It can be caused by various factors, including trauma or medical conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following actions is not typically performed in cases of Carcinoma of the Oesophagus?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • pH-metry: pH-metry is not typically performed for the evaluation of Carcinoma Oesophagus. pH-metry is a test used to measure the pH levels in the esophagus to evaluate for conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or esophageal motility disorders. It is not specific to Carcinoma Oesophagus.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Biopsy: A biopsy is typically performed to obtain a tissue sample from the suspected area of carcinoma in the esophagus. The tissue sample is then examined under a microscope to confirm the diagnosis and determine the histological type and grade of the cancer.

Option C. CT chest: A CT (computed tomography) scan of the chest is commonly performed to evaluate the extent and stage of Carcinoma Oesophagus. It helps visualize the size and location of the tumor, as well as any spread to nearby lymph nodes or distant organs.

Option D. PET scan: A PET (positron emission tomography) scan is often used to detect the spread of Carcinoma Oesophagus beyond the primary tumor site. It can help identify metastases to distant organs or lymph nodes by detecting areas of increased metabolic activity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old presents with complaints of chest and difficulty in swallowing. Based on the findings in the below image, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diffuse oesophageal spasm:

  • Diffuse oesophageal spasm is a motility disorder characterized by uncoordinated contractions of the muscles in the esophagus. This condition leads to difficulties in swallowing, chest pain, and sometimes regurgitation.
  • The X-ray image provided shows the characteristic findings associated with Diffuse Oesophageal Spasm, which include multiple contractions along the length of the esophagus, often referred to as "corkscrew" or "rosary bead" appearance.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Achalasia cardia: The X-ray image does not display the typical findings associated with Achalasia cardia, such as a dilated esophagus or absent peristalsis. Therefore, the image does not support the diagnosis of Achalasia cardia.

Option C - Carcinoma Oesophagus spasm: The X-ray image does not provide any evidence of a tumor or cancerous growth, which is a characteristic feature of Carcinoma Oesophagus spasm. Therefore, the image does not support the diagnosis of Carcinoma Oesophagus spasm.

Option D - Schatzki's Ring: The X-ray image does not show any evidence of a narrowing or ring-like structure in the esophagus, which is characteristic of Schatzki's Ring. Thus, the image does not support the diagnosis of Schatzki's Ring.

questions.text: Which of the options accurately describes the development of cancer in patients with ulcerative colitis?

choices.text: Bad prognosis if it involved only rectum
Good prognosis if it involves only rectum and is low grade
2% chance of malignancy if present for 10 years
Young age onset has low chances as compared to old age onset

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2% chance of malignancy if present for 10 years:

  • 2% chance of malignancy if present for 10 years This statement is generally true.
  • Patients with ulcerative colitis have an increased risk of developing colorectal cancer compared to the general population. The risk is directly related to the duration of the disease. It is estimated that after 10 years of ulcerative colitis, the cumulative risk of developing colorectal cancer is around 2%.
  • However, it is important to note that individual risks can vary depending on other factors such as disease severity, extent, and presence of dysplasia.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Bad prognosis if it involved only rectum This statement is not entirely accurate. While rectal involvement can increase the risk of cancer development, the prognosis is determined by multiple factors and cannot be solely based on the involvement of the rectum.

Option B - Good prognosis if it involves only rectum and is low grade- This statement is partially correct. The prognosis of colorectal cancer in ulcerative colitis can vary based on multiple factors, including the extent and grade of the cancer. However, other factors such as the presence of dysplasia, depth of invasion, and lymph node involvement also play a role in determining prognosis.

Option D - Young age onset has low chances as compared to old age onset- This statement is not entirely accurate. Young age onset does not guarantee a low chance of developing cancer, and regular surveillance and monitoring are important regardless of age.

questions.text: What is the most common immediate complication following a splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hemorrhage:

  • This is the correct option. Hemorrhage, or bleeding, is one of the most common immediate complications of splenectomy. The spleen is a highly vascular organ, and during surgery, there is a risk of bleeding from the splenic artery or its branches. Measures are taken to control bleeding during and after the procedure, but it remains a potential complication.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B - Fistula: While it is possible for a fistula to develop after splenectomy, it is not the most common immediate complication. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C - Bleeding from gastric mucosa: The spleen is not directly involved in regulating gastric mucosal integrity or bleeding control. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D - Pancreatitis:While complications related to the pancreas can occur after splenectomy in some cases, pancreatitis itself is not the most common immediate complication. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is associated with ATP7A gene causing low levels of copper in the blood stream?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Menke's disease

  • Menke's disease, also known as Menkes syndrome or copper transport disease, is a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by impaired copper absorption and transport.
  • It is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, which encodes a copper-transporting ATPase involved in the transport of copper into the cells.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by chronic jaundice due to impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin. It is not related to copper metabolism or the ATP7A gene.

Option B: Wilson's disease

  • Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to impaired copper transport and accumulation of copper in the liver and brain. It is associated with high levels of copper in tissues and low levels in the blood, but it is not caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene.

Option D: Gilbert's syndrome

  • It is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • The condition is caused by mutations in the UGT1A1 gene, which leads to reduced activity of the enzyme uridine diphosphate-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1). This enzyme is crucial for converting bilirubin into a form that can be excreted from the body.

questions.text: In which condition are macrophages observed to be positive for periodic acid Schiff staining?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Whipple's disease:

  • Whipple's disease is a rare systemic infectious disorder caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei.
  • It is characterized by infiltration of small intestinal mucosa by ‘foamy macrophages’, which stain positive with periodic acid-schiff (PAS) reagent.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Agammaglobulinemia: This statement is incorrect. Agammaglobulinemia refers to a group of primary immunodeficiency disorders characterized by a lack of mature B cells and reduced or absent immunoglobulin production.

Option C - Abetalipoproteinemia: This statement is incorrect. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the absence of beta-lipoproteins, leading to impaired absorption and transport of dietary fats and fat-soluble vitamins.

Option D - Crohn's disease: This statement is incorrect. While Crohn's disease is associated with the presence of macrophages and other immune cells in the affected intestinal tissue, PAS-positive macrophages are not a specific feature of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient was brought to the OPD with complains of fatigability, vomiting, and malaise. Examination revealed occult blood in stools, anemia, and hypertension. The patient was diagnosed to have cushing’s ulcers. What could be the likely reason for cushion’s ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Head injury:

Cushing's ulcers can develop in patients with severe head injuries, particularly those with elevated intracranial pressure. The increased intracranial pressure leads to activation of the vagus nerve, which stimulates the release of gastric acid and increases gastric motility, resulting in the development of gastric ulcers.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A. Burns: Burns are not typically associated with the development of Cushing's ulcers. Gastric ulcers in burn patients are more commonly attributed to other factors such as stress, decreased mucosal blood flow, and altered acid secretion.

Option B. Stress: While stress can contribute to the development of gastric ulcers, it is not specific to Cushing's ulcers. Stress-related ulcers, also known as stress ulcers, can occur in various conditions such as severe illness, trauma, surgery, or critical illness.

Option D. Cell necrosis: Cell necrosis alone is not a direct cause of Cushing's ulcers. The development of gastric ulcers involves complex mechanisms related to the autonomic nervous system and altered acid secretion.

questions.text: Except for which of the following, all the mentioned characteristics are associated with Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lead pipe appearance:

Lead pipe appearance: This feature is not typically associated with Crohn's disease. The term "lead pipe appearance" is used to describe the smooth, uniform narrowing of the colon seen in conditions like ulcerative colitis. In Crohn's disease, the involvement can be patchy and may lead to skip lesions or segmental involvement rather than a continuous, uniform appearance.

 

Incorrect Options

Option A - Transmural involvement: This is a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease. It refers to inflammation that extends through all layers of the intestinal wall, including the mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and serosa.

Option C - Rectal sparing: This is a feature seen in Crohn's disease. It refers to the relative sparing of the rectum from inflammation. Crohn's disease often involves the terminal ileum (the last part of the small intestine) and can extend to other parts of the gastrointestinal tract, but the rectum is commonly spared.

Option D - Perianal fistula: Perianal fistulas are frequently associated with Crohn's disease. These abnormal connections between the intestine and the skin around the anus can cause pain, discharge, and recurrent infections.

questions.text: Patient is identified as having a tumor in the ileum leading to urinary 5 HIAA being elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Carcinoid tumors:

  • Carcinoid tumors are a type of neuroendocrine tumor that can arise in various parts of the body, including the gastrointestinal tract (especially the ileum), lungs, and pancreas. They are usually slow-growing but can metastasize to other organs over time.
  • One of the hallmark features of carcinoid tumors is the secretion of serotonin, which can lead to elevated levels of urinary 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA). This is because serotonin is converted to 5-HIAA in the liver and then excreted in the urine.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B - Neuroblastoma is most commonly diagnosed in infants and young children and can cause symptoms such as abdominal swelling or pain, fever, and weight loss. Option C: Leiomyoma is a benign tumor arising from smooth muscle tissue and can occur in various parts of the body (including the uterus, gastrointestinal tract, and skin).

Option D - Chromaffinoma (also known as a pheochromocytoma) is a type of tumor arising from chromaffin cells in the adrenal glands and sympathetic ganglia (part of the autonomic nervous system).

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 50-year-old woman with a skin lesion visible in the provided image, which initially appeared small but has now spread to her entire limb and abdomen? Despite being on anticoagulation therapy, she has a longstanding history of diabetes and recurring deep vein thrombosis episodes.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Glucagonoma:

  • Based on the information provided, the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition is glucagonoma. A glucagonoma is a rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that produces excessive amounts of glucagon. Clinical features of glucagonoma
    • Diabetes mellitus/impaired glucose tolerance
    • Diarrhea
    • Dermatological features
      • Migratory necrolytic erythema (red rash- bullae- erosions)
    • Weight loss

  • Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - An insulinoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that secretes excessive amounts of insulin. This condition can lead to hypoglycemia, which can cause symptoms such as weakness, confusion, sweating, and palpitations.
  • Option B - A gastrinoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that produces excessive amounts of gastrin, a hormone that stimulates the production of stomach acid. This can cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
  • Option D - While VIPomas can cause skin lesions, they are not typically associated with recurrent deep vein thrombosis or long-standing diabetes, so it is an unlikely diagnosis in this case.
